greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If n is a square, a(n) = A000196(n), and for nonsquare n, let p be the smallest prime dividing the squarefree part of n. Divide n by p and multiply by the product of all smaller primes.
comment: Each natural numbers occurs exactly twice in this sequence.
In binary trees like A334860 and A334866, for n > 2, a(n) gives the parent node of node n.
For nonsquare numbers, n, with squarefree part A019565(k) and square part m, a(n) is the number with squarefree part A019565(k-1) and square part m. - _Peter Munn_, Jul 14 2020
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1024
mathematica: Array[If[IntegerQ[#2], #2, #1/#2*Product[Prime@i, {i, PrimePi@#2 - 1}] & @@ {#1, FactorInteger[#2 /. (c_ : 1)*a_^(b_ : 0) :> (c*a^b)^2][[1, 1]]}] & @@ {#, Sqrt[#]} &, 58] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jun 26 2020 *)
program: (PARI) A334870(n) = if(issquare(n),sqrtint(n),my(c=core(n), m=n); forprime(p=2, , if(!(c % p), m/=p; break, m*=p)); (m));
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jun 08 2020
